stem: The pediatric nurse is reviewing the developmental checklist for two children. Based on the documented physical and cognitive findings, match the behavior to the most appropriate developmental age.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1 (Mia): Brought in for an 18-month wellness visit. Parent states Mia is walking well and can say 'no' to almost everything. 
Patient 2 (Noah): Brought in for a 3-year-old wellness visit. Parent reports Noah is now playing with other children and making up 'imaginary games'.

tabs.title: Milestone Checklist
tabs.content:

### Patient 2 (Noah)

rows.text: Walking independently and using a spoon
Riding a tricycle and building a 9-block tower
Going upstairs alternating feet and showing empathy
Using 3-4 word sentences and draw a circle

rationale.correct: At **18 months**, toddlers are mastering independent walking and the use of tools like spoons (r1). Developmentally, they are in the 'autonomy vs. shame/doubt' phase, characterized by temper tantrums and the use of the word 'No' (r4). By **3 years (preschooler)**, coordination increases to allow for riding a tricycle and alternating feet on stairs (r2, r3). Language also expands to 3-4 word sentences, and symbolic/imaginary play begins (r5).
clinicalPearls: 18 months = 10-25 words. 3 years = 3-word sentences and 1,000 words.
Alternating feet on stairs is a refined motor skill expected by age 3.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that 'alternating feet' on stairs is a 2-year-old skill.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: 2-year-olds walk up stairs but usually put both feet on one step before moving to the next. Alternating is a age 3 skill.
